metadata.description: The China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD) is a high spatial-temporal resolution gridded near-surface meteorological dataset that was developed specifically for studies of land surface processes in China. The dataset was made through fusion of remote sensing products, reanalysis dataset and in-situ observation data at weather stations. Its record starts from January 1979 and keeps extending (currently up to December 2018) with a temporal resolution of three hours and a spatial resolution of 0.1°. Seven near-surface meteorological elements are provided in CMFD, including 2-meter air temperature, surface pressure, specific humidity, 10-meter wind speed, downward shortwave radiation, downward longwave radiation and precipitation rate.

background: The Earth’s surface receives both shortwave (or solar) radiation and atmospheric longwave radiation. Downward shortwave radiation (SWD) is a primary energy source of the ecosystem. In high altitude regions, SWD has become an important energy source for local people, due to the difficulties of long-distance energy supply. Meanwhile, downward longwave radiation (LWD) is an important parameter for frost prediction and for crop growing. There are only a few investigations that had been done to study the radiation conditions of high altitude regions.
research objective: This paper presented the major characteristics of SWD and LWD over the Tibetan Plateau (TP), which were measured at 11 stations built in the region. This paper presents a pilot study over TP, the highest and largest plateau in the world. First, we investigate the characteristics of shortwave and longwave radiations over high altitude regions, and point out a necessary condition for a model to be applicable over high altitude regions. Then, we evaluate two types of estimates (surface data-based estimate and satellite data-based estimate) against a long-term instrumental data set over TP.
challenges: However, it is always costly for acquiring the radiation data and there are few studies on the radiation modeling in these regions. Therefore, suitable instrumental SWD and LWD data are invaluable but they are rarely available, and an effective method developed for estimating radiation occurring over high altitude regions is very important and urgently needed.
methods: We investigated this issue at Anduo site, which has the longest records among all the TP sites, and found that the observed trends of monthly-mean SWD and LWD are consistent with the ones derived from independent modeling and satellite estimates to be presented in this study. In this study, CMA provides long-term data sets of daily-mean air temperature, relative humidity, sunshine duration, and pressure, and thus provides a possibility to extend radiation data from satellite era to earlier decades. For the surface radiation modeling in this study, SWD is estimated by a hybrid model and LWD is estimated by CD99 model. At four CMA stations (SQH, Gerze, Naqu, Anduo) where experimental radiation data are available, SWD was estimated from CMA daily data of sunshine duration, air temperature, air pressure, and humidity by the hybrid model. The estimated SWD data together with CMA air temperature and humidity data were supplied into CD99 model, which, in turn, estimated LWD values.
dataset: This paper presented the major characteristics of SWD and LWD over the Tibetan Plateau (TP), which were measured at 11 stations built in the region.
findings: The results showed that LWD received by TP is much lower than that of its surrounding areas and their monthly-mean differences can be up to 100 W m. On the contrary, SWD over TP is significantly higher than that over its surrounding areas, due to low extinction rate of airmass, water vapor, and aerosol occurred in TP. It is found that the surface data-based estimate, though not calibrated locally, shows a good agreement with the measurements and has an advantage of producing less root-mean-square errors and higher correlation coefficients than the satellite estimates.

background: The China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD) is the first high spatial-temporal resolution gridded near-surface meteorological dataset developed specifically for studies of land surface processes in China. Validations against observations measured at independent stations show that the CMFD is of superior quality than the GLDAS (Global Land Data Assimilation System); this is because a larger number of stations are used to generate the CMFD than are utilised in the GLDAS. Due to its continuous temporal coverage and consistent quality, the CMFD is one of the most widely-used climate datasets for China.
research objective: Since 2008, we have used this precious data-sharing opportunity to develop the first high-resolution meteorological dataset, called the China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD) and based on the released CMA data. Although this dataset was intended to provide a better dataset to drive a variety of terrestrial models over China, it has already been applied to much broader fields.
challenges: On the one hand, the spatial resolution of the stated datasets is not high enough to depict complex weather/climate patterns over the mountainous terrain in mid-west China. On the other, the generation of such datasets necessitates ground-based observations as inputs. However, observations at only a small fraction of weather stations from the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) are shared world-wide via the Global Telecommunication System (GTS), which prevents data developers from improving their dataset quality over China.
methods: The ground-based observations used in this study come from two data sources: those acquired from CMA’s CMDC are daily data from approximately 700 stations, while those from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)’s National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI) are sub-daily data with only 300–400 stations available over China for most years. Because both datasets are CMA weather station data, we will not distinguish them, and collectively call them CMA data throughout the remainder of this paper. The core of the algorithms for temperature, pressure, specific humidity and wind speed is summarized in Fig. 2a. The five main steps in this algorithm are listed as follows. (1) Interpolate 3-hourly gridded background data (GLDAS or MERRA) at the location of each CMA weather station. (2) Subtract interpolated background data from step (1) by 3-hourly observations at each station, obtaining the discrepancies between these two kinds of datasets. (3) Interpolate these discrepancies from stations to 0.1° grid points using ANUSPLIN software. (4) Remap the background data from its resolution to 0.1° grid. (5) Add the gridded discrepancies in step (3) to the output of step (4), to get the corrected data product. The procedure for generating downward shortwave radiation data (Fig. 2b) is different to that for generating temperature, pressure, specific humidity, and wind speed. The procedure for generating downward shortwave radiation data is listed as follows. (1) Interpolate 3-hourly gridded background data (GLDAS or GEWEX-SRB) at the location of each CMA weather stations. (2) Estimate the daily mean downward shortwave radiation with the hybrid model based on weather station data. (3) Calculate the ratio of the data from step (2) and the daily mean downward shortwave radiation from step (1). (4) Interpolate the ratio from stations to 0.1° grid points and obtain the gridded ratio. (5) Remap the background data from its resolution to 0.1° grid. (6) Multiply the gridded ratio in step (4) with the 3-hourly output of step (5), to get the corrected data product. First, we made a 0.1-degree, 3-hourly precipitation dataset through the interpolation algorithm similar to that of the temperature; the interpolation uses observational and 3-hourly gridded precipitation background data as inputs (see the upper-left block in Fig. 2c). Second, a 0.1-degree, monthly precipitation dataset was made using the same interpolation algorithm, but using monthly observational and gridded precipitation background data as inputs (see the upper-right block in Fig. 2c). Third, the ratio of this monthly precipitation data and the monthly precipitation derived from the 3-hourly precipitation dataset is calculated on each grid cell for each month. The ratio is then used as a correction factor to multiply the 3-hourly precipitation values on the grid for the month, which yields the final precipitation product (see the lower block in Fig. 2c).
dataset: The dataset was made through fusion of remote sensing products, reanalysis datasets and in-situ station data. Its record begins in January 1979 and is ongoing (currently up to December 2018) with a temporal resolution of three hours and a spatial resolution of 0.1°. Seven near-surface meteorological elements are provided in the CMFD, including 2-meter air temperature, surface pressure, and specific humidity, 10-meter wind speed, downward shortwave radiation, downward longwave radiation and precipitation rate.

Where do the data sources for constructing high-resolution meteorological datasets typically come from?
Concept Completion.Answer: Remote sensing products, reanalysis datasets, in-situ station data

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to create a high-resolution meteorological dataset in China?
Example.Answer: A method involves using ground-based observations from CMA’s CMDC and NOAA’s NCEI, interpolating 3-hourly gridded background data at each weather station, and using ANUSPLIN software to interpolate discrepancies to 0.1° grid points, which are then added to remapped background data.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in generating high-resolution datasets for complex terrains in China?
Example.Answer: A challenge is that the spatial resolution of datasets is often not high enough to capture complex weather patterns over mountainous regions, and limited sharing of ground-based observations via the Global Telecommunication System restricts improvements in dataset quality.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of meteorological datasets used for land surface process simulations in China?
Feature Specification.Answer: high spatial-temporal resolution, temporal resolution of three hours, spatial resolution of 0.1°, 2-meter air temperature, surface pressure, specific humidity, 10-meter wind speed, downward shortwave radiation, downward longwave radiation, precipitation rate

Feature Specification.Question: What specific features are considered when estimating downward shortwave radiation in high altitude regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: sunshine duration, air temperature, air pressure, humidity

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges in creating high-resolution meteorological datasets for complex terrains in China?
Feature Specification.Answer: insufficient spatial resolution, reliance on ground-based observations, limited sharing of observational data

Quantification.Question: What is the temporal resolution of the meteorological dataset provided for the China region?

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'ANU-Spline statistical interpolation' in the context of meteorological data processing?
Definition.Answer: ANU-Spline statistical interpolation is a method used to interpolate discrepancies between datasets and generate corrected data products. It is employed to create gridded data points from station observations, ensuring the resulting data has improved spatial resolution and accuracy relative to the original datasets.

Definition.Question: What does 'fusion of remote sensing products, reanalysis datasets, and in-situ station data' mean in the creation of meteorological datasets?
Definition.Answer: Fusion of remote sensing products, reanalysis datasets, and in-situ station data refers to the process of combining these different data sources to create a meteorological dataset. This approach enhances the dataset's accuracy and spatial-temporal resolution by integrating satellite data, historical reanalysis data, and ground-based observations.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when collecting meteorological data over high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau compared to mid-west China?
Comparison.Answer: The challenges in collecting meteorological data over high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau include the high cost of acquiring suitable instrumental data and the scarcity of studies on radiation modeling in these regions. In contrast, challenges in mid-west China include the insufficient spatial resolution of datasets to depict complex weather patterns and limited ground-based observations shared globally, which affects data quality improvement. Both regions face difficulties due to their unique geographical and climatic conditions.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the combination of reanalysis data, satellite remote sensing data, and in-situ station data enhance the understanding of climate patterns over large regions like China?
Interpretation.Answer: By fusing these data sources, datasets can leverage the strengths of each: the extensive spatial and temporal coverage of reanalysis and satellite data, combined with the precision of in-situ observations, provides a comprehensive view of climate patterns. This fusion allows for more accurate simulations and analyses of land surface processes, particularly in resolving fine-scale climatic features and trends.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to address discrepancies between background data and observational data in meteorological dataset development?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Addressing discrepancies between background data and observational data is crucial in meteorological dataset development to enhance the accuracy of the final dataset. Such discrepancies arise due to differences in data collection methods, spatial coverage, and resolution. Correcting these discrepancies ensures that the dataset provides reliable and precise meteorological information suitable for land surface process studies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What underlying factors contribute to the challenges of acquiring accurate radiation data in high altitude regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The acquisition of accurate radiation data in high altitude regions is challenged by the limited availability of ground-based observational stations and the high cost of acquiring such data. Additionally, the complex terrain and atmospheric conditions in these regions require sophisticated models and data integration techniques to estimate radiation levels accurately, further complicating data collection efforts.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended goals behind developing a high spatial-temporal resolution gridded meteorological dataset specifically for land surface processes in China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals include providing a better dataset to drive terrestrial models over China and improving the quality of meteorological datasets, as the CMFD dataset offers superior quality compared to existing datasets by using a larger number of stations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of using multiple data sources, like CMA and NOAA data, in the development of meteorological datasets over China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose is to increase the dataset's resolution and accuracy by utilizing a wide range of observations, which allows for more precise interpolation and correction of meteorological variables, addressing limitations in spatial resolution and data availability over complex terrains.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to integrate satellite remote sensing data with ground-based meteorological observations in creating a high-resolution meteorological dataset for regional climate studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The integration process involves fusing remote sensing products, reanalysis datasets, and in-situ station data. The methodology includes interpolating gridded background data (GLDAS or similar) at weather station locations, calculating discrepancies, and using interpolation software like ANUSPLIN to map these discrepancies onto a 0.1° grid. This process is repeated for each meteorological variable, including temperature, pressure, specific humidity, and wind speed, ensuring a consistent and high-resolution dataset.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the estimation of downward shortwave and longwave radiation data conducted in regions with limited instrumental data, such as high-altitude areas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In regions with limited data, a hybrid model is used to estimate downward shortwave radiation (SWD) based on available weather station data like sunshine duration, air temperature, and humidity. The CD99 model is employed to estimate downward longwave radiation (LWD) using inputs from the hybrid model. This approach leverages long-term datasets from meteorological agencies and satellite data to extend and enhance radiation data coverage over challenging terrains.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the main procedural steps involved in generating high-resolution precipitation data using a combination of observational and gridded background data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Generating high-resolution precipitation data involves creating a 0.1-degree, 3-hourly precipitation dataset through an interpolation algorithm that uses both observational data and 3-hourly gridded background data. The process includes calculating the ratio between monthly precipitation data and monthly precipitation derived from the 3-hourly dataset, which is then used as a correction factor to refine the precipitation values, resulting in a comprehensive precipitation product for the region.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in statistical interpolation techniques enhance the accuracy of meteorological datasets in complex terrains?
Enablement.Answer: Statistical interpolation techniques, like ANUSPLIN, allow for the precise estimation of meteorological variables by correcting discrepancies between interpolated background data and ground observations. This method improves the resolution and accuracy of datasets, particularly in regions with complex terrains where observational data might be sparse.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or resources are necessary for producing a high-resolution meteorological dataset with continuous temporal coverage over an extensive geographic area?
Enablement.Answer: Producing such a dataset requires a combination of high-resolution reanalysis data, satellite observations, and a dense network of ground-based weather stations. Continuous temporal coverage is facilitated by integrating long-term records from sources like CMA and NOAA, alongside advanced algorithms for interpolation and data fusion.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to accurately model radiation conditions in high altitude regions using existing datasets?
Expectation.Answer: It is always costly for acquiring radiation data, and there are few studies on radiation modeling in these regions. Suitable instrumental data are invaluable but rarely available, making effective estimation methods for high altitude regions urgently needed.

Expectation.Question: Why might datasets developed for land surface processes in China have superior quality compared to global datasets like GLDAS?
Expectation.Answer: Validations against observations show that datasets developed for China have superior quality, potentially due to the use of a larger number of stations for data generation, allowing for more accurate depiction of weather and climate patterns.

Expectation.Question: Why do spatial resolution and availability of ground-based observations pose challenges in creating datasets for complex terrains like mid-west China?
Expectation.Answer: The spatial resolution of datasets may not be high enough to depict complex weather/climate patterns in mountainous terrains, and the limited sharing of ground-based observations worldwide restricts the ability to improve dataset quality.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the main challenges in producing high spatial-temporal resolution meteorological datasets over complex terrains, and how can these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges include the lack of high-density observational data and the difficulty in capturing complex weather patterns over mountainous terrains. These challenges can be addressed by improving the spatial resolution of datasets through advanced interpolation techniques like ANUSPLIN, and incorporating a larger number of ground-based observations for better accuracy. Additionally, using hybrid models to combine different data types can help improve dataset quality over complex terrains.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data from multiple sources like satellite, reanalysis datasets, and in-situ observations can be integrated to improve the accuracy of a meteorological dataset.
Assertion.Answer: The integration is achieved by using a fusion process that combines remote sensing products, reanalysis datasets, and in-situ station data. This process uses interpolation techniques such as ANUSPLIN to correct and refine the data, resulting in a dataset with improved accuracy compared to using any single data source alone.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the challenges involved in collecting and modeling radiation data in high altitude regions.
Assertion.Answer: The challenges include the high cost and limited availability of radiation data, as well as the complexity of modeling radiation in these regions. To address this, data from long-term instrumental records are supplemented with estimates from surface-based and satellite-based models, like the hybrid model for shortwave radiation and the CD99 model for longwave radiation, ensuring consistent and reliable datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the potential methods for extending meteorological datasets from the satellite era to earlier decades using available data sources.
Request/Directive.Answer: Extending meteorological datasets from the satellite era to earlier decades can be achieved by utilizing long-term datasets from sources like the China Meteorological Administration (CMA), which provides historical data on air temperature, relative humidity, sunshine duration, and pressure. By using these historical records as a basis, along with models like the CD99 for longwave radiation, it is possible to estimate past conditions. The use of a hybrid model for shortwave radiation and the integration of daily and sub-daily data from various stations further enable the extension of datasets into earlier periods, ensuring continuity and consistency in meteorological data coverage.
